cards.title: Intro
cards.body: A JavaScript cheat sheet with the most important concepts, functions, methods, and more. A complete quick reference for beginners.

cards.title: Introduction
cards.body: JavaScript is a lightweight, interpreted programming language.

cards.title: Console
Variables
Strings
Comments
Assignment Operators
String Interpolation
let Keyword
const Keyword
if Statement
Ternary Operator
Operators
cards.code:
true || false; // true
10 > 5 || 10 > 20; // true
false || false; // false
10 > 100 || 10 > 20; // false

cards.title: Operators
cards.code:
true && true; // true
1 > 2 && 2 > 1; // false
true && false; // false
4 === 4 && 3 > 1; // true

cards.title: Operators
Operators
cards.code:
null ?? 'I win'; //  'I win'
undefined ?? 'Me too'; //  'Me too'

false ?? 'I lose'; //  false
0 ?? 'I lose again'; //  0
'' ?? 'Damn it'; //  ''

cards.title: else if
switch Statement
== vs ===
cards.code:
0 == false; // true
0 === false; // false, different type
1 == '1'; // true,  automatic type conversion
1 === '1'; // false, different type
null == undefined; // true
null === undefined; // false
'0' == false; // true
'0' === false; // false

cards.title: == vs ===
cards.body: The `==` just check the value, `===` check both the value and the type.

Scope
Block Scoped Variables

let vs var
let vs var
let vs var
cards.body: `var` is scoped to the nearest function block, and `let` is scoped to the nearest enclosing block.

cards.title: Loops with closures
Loops with closures
Loops with closures
cards.code:
The variable has its own copy using `let`, and the variable has shared copy using `var`.

## JavaScript Arrays

### Arrays

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.body:
// Different data types
const data = [1, 'chicken', false];

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.body:
// Accessing an array element
const myArray = [100, 200, 300];

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.code:
### Mutable chart

|           | add | remove | start | end |
| :-------- | :-: | :----: | :---: | :-: |
| `push`    | ✔  |        |       | ✔  |
| `pop`     |     |   ✔   |       | ✔  |
| `unshift` | ✔  |        |  ✔   |     |
| `shift`   |     |   ✔   |  ✔   |     |

{.show-header}

### Array.push()

cards.title: Loops with closures
Loops with closures
Loops with closures
cards.code:
Add items to the end and returns the new array length.

### Array.pop()

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.code:
Remove an item from the end and returns the removed item.

### Array.shift()

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.code:
Remove an item from the beginning and returns the removed item.

### Array.unshift()

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.code:
Add items to the beginning and returns the new array length.

### Array.concat()

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.code:
If you want to avoid mutating your original array, you can use concat.

## JavaScript Set

### Create Set

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.body:
// Empty Set Object
const emptySet = new Set();

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.body:
// Set Object with values
const setObj = new Set([1, true, 'hi']);

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.body:
// add values
emptySet.add('a'); // 'a'
emptySet.add(1); // 'a', 1
emptySet.add(true); // 'a', 1, true
emptySet.add('a'); // 'a', 1, true

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.body:
// delete values
emptySet.delete('a'); // 1, true
emptySet.delete(true); // 1
emptySet.delete(1); //

cards.title: Loops with closures
cards.body:
// returns true or false
setObj.has('a'); // true
setObj.has(1); // true
setObj.has(false); // false
